CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6+6-3-c - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing) (Article 6 - Right to a fair trial;Article 6-3-c - Defence through legal assistance);Violation of Article 34 - Individual applications (Article 34 - Hinder the exercise of the right of petition)
JUDGES: Dmitry Dedov;Elisabeth Steiner;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Julia Laffranque;Khanlar Hajiyev;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Paulo Pinto De Albuquerque
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is now serving his sentence in a correctional colony in the GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested and charged with double murder and attempted murder .
CARDINAL . During the trial the applicant was represented by ORG - appointed counsel , PERSON
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , in a trial by jury , convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to DATE and QUANTITY months’ imprisonment .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , unassisted by counsel . He submitted , in particular , that he had acted in self - defence and asked for reduction of the sentence from murder to manslaughter .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was notified that the appeal hearing would be held on DATE . According to the Government , his counsel , PERSON , was also informed by telegram of the date of the appeal hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE held an appeal hearing . The applicant and the prosecutor were present . Counsel PERSON did not attend . According to the applicant , he had asked for replacement counsel to be appointed for him . According to the Government , no such request had been made . On DATE the court upheld the conviction and reduced the sentence to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant was transferred to correctional colony no . PERSON in GPE , where he remained until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG sent the applicant at his request the text of the ORG , an application form together with the explanatory note , an authority form , and the notice to applicants . On DATE the letter was received by the GPE remand centre where the applicant had been previously held . It was opened , stamped , and then transferred to colony no . PERSON in GPE .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , on DATE a deputy head of ORG had summoned him and strongly advised him not to submit an application to the ORG . Immediately after this conversation he had been put in a disciplinary cell for DATE . According to the ORG ’s account , it was the applicant who had asked for a meeting with the official . At the applicant ’s request , the official had explained to him the procedure for applying to the ORG . He had not made any threats . The applicant had then been put into a disciplinary cell for having sent a letter through informal channels instead of sending it via the detention facility ’s administration .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ’s letter of DATE was received by the staff of colony no . FAC and was opened and stamped . According to the applicant , he had received the covering letter of DATE and the text of the Convention on DATE . The other enclosures and the envelope had not been given to him . According to the Government , all the enclosures had been handed over to the applicant on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sent an improvised application form to the ORG .

CARDINAL . The applicant stated that on DATE he had been summoned by the head of correctional colony no . CARDINAL in GPE , who had issued the threat that if he did not stop complaining , he would regret it . According to the Government , it was the applicant who had asked for a meeting with the head of the correctional colony . No threats had been made to the applicant during the meeting .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was temporarily transferred to medical correctional facility no . CARDINAL in GPE for anti - tuberculosis treatment .

CARDINAL . The applicant stated that on DATE he had handed a sealed envelope containing a letter to the ORG to the medical correctional facility ’s administration . The letter had been opened , stamped and dispatched to the addressee . The ORG stated that the applicant had handed the letter to the detention facility staff unsealed .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , the detention facility ’s administration had refused to dispatch many of his letters to the ORG , and he had therefore had to send them through informal channels . The ORG stated that all his letters had been dispatched .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant complained to various ORG authorities about the opening of and the failure to dispatch his letters to the ORG . In a letter dated DATE , the prosecutor ’s office informed the applicant that there had been no evidence of any failure to dispatch his letters .

CARDINAL . On DATE the medical correctional facility ’s administration received another letter from the ORG addressed to the applicant acknowledging receipt of his correspondence . That letter was opened , stamped and then given to the applicant . The employee who had opened the letter was subsequently disciplined .
